content.description:
A Farewell to Anchises

Coniugioconiugium, -i, n. = conubium, -i, AnchisaAnchises, -ae, m.: Anchises (the father of Aeneas),1 VenerisVenus, -eris, f.: the goddess Venus Venus, -eris, f.: the goddess Venusdignatedigno, -are, -avi, -atum: to consider worthy superbo, 
cura deumdeum = deorum, bisbis, adv.: twice PergameisPergameus, -a, -um, adj. = Troianus, -a, -um erepte ruinisruina, -ae, f.: ruin, 
ecce tibi AusoniaeAusonia, -ae, f. = Italia, -ae tellus: hanc arripe arripio, -ere = capio, -erevelisvelum, -i, n.: sail.
 1:Anchisa = voc. sing.↩
content.question: In line 1, which of the following words does superbo modify?

unit.text: 5: Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 4, 6, 7, 11, and 12

skill.text: 1.B: Describe how grammar contributes to the meaning and function of Latin words and phrases in context.
